awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Advanced Artificial Intelligence for Robotic E-Commerce Pick-and-Pack Automation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to improve the resiliency of the supply chain by implementing flexible robotic systems for materials handling.  The robotic systems that are controlled by artificial intelligence. E-commerce sales are increasing 20% year over year. During the COVID-19 pandemic additional retail volume shifted online and many customers became accustomed to sourcing essentials using e-commerce. This shift has put a greater burden on asupply chain infrastructure that has traditionally relied on human labor to pick, sort, pack, and process items for delivery. These manual processes are monotonous, error-prone, and sometimes dangerous, have extremely high worker turnover. The automation of these processes elevates worker roles and brings greater consistency to the processes. The innovation developed during this Phase II project may enable broader automation of complex materials handling processes by creating novel training systems for artificial intelligence-enabled robotic systems that are configured specifically for individual customer needs. This innovation may increase US supply chain resilience, enabling citizens to rapidly and reliably obtain necessities such as food, medicine, and health supplies without needing to leave their homes. The commercial opportunity is large, with over $20B spent on US pick and pack wages annually.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to develop new methods for rapidly training artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled robotic systems built for object identification and manipulation. Warehouse object manipulation tasks are variable and automating them often requires custom solutions for each customer and facility. These custom solutions are often prohibitively expensive. To solve these problems, an industrial operating system that can be deployed across many configurations of materials handling processes is required. This project aims to develop modules critical to scaling commercial deployments, such as quality control vision systems, automated assessments of item pickability, and enhanced AI systems for robotic picking. The anticipated result of this project is an industrial AI-enabled robotic operating system that allows rapid configuration of robotic systems to implement highly-optimized processes for picking and packing individual items in e-commerce logistics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Ecommerce sales in the US have grown a staggering 85% from 2019 to 2023 in part due to the Covid-19 pandemic, and sales are expected to increase over 50% by 2028. However, a major challenge for on-time online order delivery is the high dependence on manual processes for sorting and packing individual items. Existing processes are tedious and injury-prone, making it challenging to attract and retain labor. 

Robots that can be rapidly configured to pick and pack applications with a wide variety of items have the potential to automate repetitive motions and enable humans to focus on less strenuous tasks such as exception handling and value-added services. However, the ability to pick, scan, and pack novel objects without tedious item-specific training has been a major technological barrier to automation in ecommerce fulfillment. New robotic capabilities and technologies are needed to adapt to new items and packages in response to the high variance of real-world warehouse operations.

This NSF SBIR Phase II project extended developments from the NSF SBIR Phase I project to enable AI-powered robots to operate with high reliability and throughput in real warehouse environments. The project focused on five core tasks: developing detection systems for multi-item picks to avoid costly missorts, developing classification systems for unpickable items, improving picking vision systems using novel neural network training paradigms, implementing continuous learning systems, and integrating these develops into a commercial system for sorting and packing a wide variety of items.

A key outcome of this project was the development of several AI models that serve to increase the productivity of robotic machines in production. We developed quality control neural networks to accurately detect when a robot has picked multiple items, helping improve production sort accuracy to well above 99%. We also deployed an item tracking system that can be used to detect repeated failures and unpickable items, helping to improve throughput and reduce interventions. We built a new version of the robotic pick planning AI that can rapidly plan a set of grasps on each item, improving pick success rate and throughput to well over 400 sorts an hour. We deployed a continuous learning pipeline that automatically re-trains neural networks based on production data. Finally, we developed enhancements to the AmbiSort A-Series robotic machine for parcel sorting that would enable the machine to automatically feed itself packages and reject unpickable items.

During the course of this project, Ambi Robotics deployed a large number of the AmbiSort A-Series robotic package sorting machines into commercial production with customers. Most enhancements developed in this project were moved into production as software or hardware updates, resulting in significantly improved performance. Over the peak holiday season 2023, Ambi Robotic machines sorted well over 1 million packages per week in production at a throughput over 30% higher than the contracted rate, with over 99.5% uptime. Through surveys of operations managers and robot operators who use the machines, we also identified that the machines are perceived as a significant improvement over previous processes and provide a better working environment for employees.

Ambi Robotics has now raised over $67 million in private venture funding and continues to grow its commercial deployments.

Overall, the results of this project have led to significant utilization of robots for parcel sorting in ecommerce order delivery, contributing to the advancement of US welfare and prosperity by improving the reliability of the ecommerce supply chain and increasing worker satisfaction.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2024
Modified by: Jeffrey Mahler
